I'd just like to add that the serial numbered swords are limited to
the NCO=
 shin guntos with aluminium cast handle. I have seen many other
so-called J=
apanese swords with serial numbers on the blade, and these
were almost all =
Chinese fakes. For some reason, they think this
increases the value or legi=
timacy.
After the war, most of the civilian swords (bar a few identified as=

art objects) were confiscated, not registered.
There is very little chance=
 of tracking down the original owners or
history of 99% of these swords.

R=
egards,
Brian

>
> Hello David - 
> 
> Welcome and Happy 2006 to you too. 
=
> 
> If you have a sword with a serial number stamped on it (on the
blade) =
then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made" sword.
Sometimes you=
 will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) of a
sword, usually tw=
o or three digits, which in that case might relate to
"assembly" numbers; t=
hese same numbers are often repeated on seppa,
tsuba, etc. Swords were "reg=
istered" after the war and continue to be
so today, but the Japanese govern=
ment never required anything
(registration numbers) to be stamped on swords=
. 
> 
> Ron
> STL
